clinical_study.official_title: Haloperidol vs. Valproate in the Management of Agitated Patients Presenting to the Emergency Department: A Randomized Clinical Trial

brief_summary.textblock: The aim of this study is to compare the efficacy of haloperidol and valproate in management of people with agitation in emergency department

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Subject, Caregiver, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Treatment

primary_outcome.measure: Reduction in Agitated Behavior Scale (ABS) score
primary_outcome.time_frame: within the first 30 minutes of treatment onset
primary_outcome.description: Patients were rated before medication administration and within 30 minutes afterwards according to Agitated Behavior Scale (ABS) score. Any statistically significant change in ABS score consider as positive effect of either intervention.

arm_group.description: Valproate single Infusion; 400 mg (weigh<60 kg), 500 mg (weight>60 Kg)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Clinical diagnosis of psychomotor agitation
- aged 18 to 65 years
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pregnant patients
- Severe liver disease
- History of drug (haloperidol/valproate) allergy
- Readily amendable causes for the agitation (hypoxemia or hypoglycemia)
- Hypotension (systolic blood pressure (SBP) â‰¤ 90 mm Hg)
- Known history of liver disease or uncontrolled diabetes
- Noticeable or suspected head trauma
- Previous history of neuroleptic malignant syndrome
- Receiving psychotropic medication, neuroleptic agents or cholinesterase inhibitors at the time of enrollment
